Pre Check-In Easy Referral

Patients

Examination & Testing

Our highly skilled ophthalmic technicians are experts in data collection and will perform a series of tests prior to your consultation with the doctor in order to ensure that your doctor has complete and accurate information available to properly assess and manage your problem.

Our ophthalmic technicians are trained opticians and optometrists with superior knowledge and skill relative to the industry standard. They have advanced training in eye care and can help to guide you through your visit, as well as address any questions or concerns you may have.

We are a technology focused office where we focus on heavy utilization of ophthalmic imaging to take pictures of your eye, rather than simply examining your eye with a microscope and making notes as we used to. We believe that this allows us to better document and assess your eye, as well as to show you what we are seeing so that we can better explain to you, and educate you, regarding your eye problems

Visual Acuity

  • If you wear a corrective lenses for distance, whether glasses or contact lenses, please wear your lenses for the assessment.
  • Our ophthalmic technicians will test your distance vision one eye at a time.
  • If your vision is not “perfect,” you may be asked to look through a pinhole device to see if your vision improves; this helps us to determine the cause of the imperfect vision.

Auto-Refraction

  • Our ophthalmic technicians will use a specialized instrument to automatically check the refractive error, i.e. the strength of your prescription, in your eye.
  • This is a very quick and simple test that does not require any eye drops, and is not uncomfortable.

Eye Pressure

iCare Non Contact Tonometry

  • Our ophthalmic technicians will use a handheld instrument to check the eye pressure for all patients.
  • This is a very quick and simple test that does not require any eye drops, does not touch the eye, and is not uncomfortable. This test is tolerated very well by both children and adults.

Goldman Applanation Tonometry

  • In glaucoma cases, or cases where eye pressure is a concern, the doctor may take an additional eye pressure measurement using a special instrument attached to the microscope.
  • This is a quick and simple test that does require freezing eye drops, as well as an orange dye, to be dropped in the eye, but it is not uncomfortable.

Anterior Segment Imaging

  • Our ophthalmic technicians may take color photographs of the anterior, or front, part of your eye using a specialized microscope and camera with 4K resolution; these images will be stored in your chart for the doctor to review, and as a baseline reference to compare against at future visits.
  • These photographs take approximately one minute to capture, and, other than some bright lights, are not uncomfortable. In most cases, we will put a freezing drop, with orange dye, in your eye before taking these photographs in order to better see corneal pathology.

Fundus Photography

  • Our ophthalmic technicians may take color photographs of the fundus, or the back of the eye, i.e. the optic nerve, macular, and the central portion of the retina; these images will be stored in your chart for the doctor to review, and as a baseline reference to compare against at future visits.
  • These photographs take approximately one minute to capture, and, other than some bright lights, are not uncomfortable

Angle Photography; Nidek GS-1 Gonioscope

  • Our ophthalmic technicians may take true color photographs of the angle, i.e. the space between the cornea and the iris, of your eye using a specialized instrument; these images will be stored in your chart for the doctor to review, and as a baseline reference to compare against at future visits.
  • The angle is an important structure of the eye, that is difficult to visualize on exam, and is therefore often underassessed. The angle is of critical importance when assessing both cataract and glaucoma and the gonioscope allows us to better assess and document the status of your angle. The Nidek GS-1 gonioscope was released in Canada in Jan 2021; we chose to invest in it because we believe that it provides valuable information about your eye, that can help us to formulate the best treatment plan for you and capture pathology that is otherwise frequently missed.
  • These images take approximately two minutes to capture. In order to visualize the angle of the eye and take the images, we must give you eye drops to freeze your eye and then place a sticky gel and a contact lens on the surface of the eye to acquire these images. Other than the gel and contact feeling sticky and a bit awkward, the process is not uncomfortable.

Other

Depending on the reason for referral, or the type of problem, the doctor may ask the ophthalmic technician to perform other additional tests as required, including: pupils, color vision, Hertel exophthalmometry, cover testing, and extraocular eye movements. If required, these tests will be explained to you before they are performed.
